agent.@description: Web-based interface for submitting, editing, and reviewing studies in the Open Tree of Life project.

annotation.@description: Aids for mapping study OTUs to OTT taxa
Describes external namesets merged into this study
Describes supporting data files for this study

description.$: Timetree of Atelopus diversification from a relaxed-clock MCMC Bayesian analysis using the software BEAST 2, calibrated using mitochondrial DNA substitution rates of mitochondrial genes of bufonid frog. This tree serves as the basis for Figure 3 and Supplementary Figure 3 of Ramirez et al. (2020)

50% bootstrap consensus tree corresponding to the maximum likelihood (ML) analysis inferred from DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes
(COI and cyt b) from the species of Atelopus of Central and South America presented in Ramirez et al. (2020). The bootstrap support values reported in this tree were presented in the ML tree shown in Figure 2 and Supplementary Figure 2 of Ramirez et al. (2020)

Maximum likelihood (ML) tree inferred from DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and cyt b) from the species of Atelopus of Central and South America. This tree serves as the basis for Figure 2 and Supplementary Figure 2 of Ramirez et al. (2020)

50% bootstrap consensus tree corresponding to the Maximum Parsimony (MP) analysis inferred from DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and cyt b) for samples of Atelopus of Central and South America. The bootstrap support values reported in this tree were presented in the MP tree shown in Supplementary Figure 1 of Ramirez et al. (2020)

One of the 97 most-parsimonious trees (selected arbitrarily) inferred from DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and cyt b) for samples of Atelopus of Central and South America. This tree serves as the basis for Supplementary Figure 1 of Ramirez et al. (2020)

nexml.^ot:studyPublicationReference: Ramírez, J., Jaramillo, C., Lindquist, E., Crawford, A., & Ibáñez, R. (2020). Recent and Rapid Radiation of the Highly Endangered Harlequin Frogs (Atelopus) into Central America Inferred from Mitochondrial DNA Sequences. Diversity, 12(9), 360. doi:10.3390/d12090360
